learning_outcomes.description: Sketch the evolution of the Australian labour law system, and the constitutional, workplace relations and industrial political factors underlying it.
Understand the national statutory regime (The Fair Work Act) and its key obligations and freedoms, in the context of the common law contractual framework.
Describe the mechanisms and parameters for fixing employment conditions and obligations under the national system.
Appreciate the role of key regulatory institutions, such as the Fair Work Commission and trade unions.
Apply specific knowledge acquired in the course to answer both hypothetical questions (particularly on dismissal law) and engage in longer, more critical debates about labour law.

assessments.assessment_title: Written assignment - hypothetical advice on a contract of employment
assessments.task_description:
This assignment will cover content from weeks 2-4 of the course (the contract of employment, the NES and awards). You will write a 1500 word letter of advice to an employer about a proposed contract of employment.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.assessment_title: Oral presentation - opening statements and discussion in a mock conciliation format (group work)
assessments.due_date:
4/05/2026 - 16/05/2026

Groups must present as a team, at the same time as an 'opposing' team. There will be a range of times available in weeks 10 and 11 including outside business hours.
assessments.task_description:
Step 1: Group work oral presentation - opening statements (30%)

This assessment develops a key skill for employment law advocates and lawyers - presenting/advancing your client's position in a conference format. In our case this will be a conciliation conference about a dismissal from employment. We will focus on the first part of a standard conciliation conference - presenting opening statements and discussion. This assessment will be supported by a lecture in week 7 on dispute resolution, focusing on mediation/conciliation, and a tutorial exploring the skills necessary to undertake the task. It will test knowledge developed in weeks 5 - 8.

In pairs or groups of three, students will prepare a seven-minute oral opening statement representing either the employee or the employer. Students will have at least four weeks to prepare their opening statements. Students may select their own partner or group, or choose to be allocated by the course coordinator to a group of three. All group members must be involved in the preparation and agree on the final statement to be delivered.

Students will then present their opening statement in an in-person simulated conference environment. Students may choose one or more group members to deliver the opening statement. After opening statements are presented, there will be discussion (questions, answers, further comments). All students must be prepared to participate in discussion. Each conference will last 30 minutes. Conferences will be recorded for moderation purposes.

Conferences will be scheduled during weeks 10 and 11. To ensure equitable access, some times will be outside business hours. All group members will receive the same mark for the group work component. More information about this assessment will be provided in lectures and tutorials.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
This will be a centrally timetabled end-of-semester exam, sat in-person.

You will have 90 minutes working time, plus 10 minutes planning time.

Like any exam, you need to prepare well, beforehand. That is, you need to have synthesised the lectures, tutorials and readings, prior to the exam period.

There will be 2 questions, worth a total of 40 marks. There may be a mixture of essay, problem and shorter-answer questions. 

In the final lecture, more information will be given as to coverage and format. 

The exam is closed book.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

The programme of lectures for the course is:

  1. Introduction to employment law
  2. The contract of employment 1 - employment contracts
  3. The contract of employment 2 - categories of employees, regulated workers, volunteers etc
  4. Minimum employment standards: NES and awards
  5. Above minimum standards: bargaining, industrial action and enterprise agreements
  6. Dispute resolution essentials for employment lawyers
  7. Workplace protections 1 - general protections and discrimination
  8. Workplace protections 2 - sexual harassment, bullying and positive duties
  9. Dismissal from employment 1 - unfair dismissal
  10. Dismissal from employment 2 - redundancy, transfer of business and 'unfair deactivation'
  11. Human rights at work
  12. Emerging issues in employment law (note, if we are scheduled for Friday lectures, 11 and 12 may be combined because we will not have a lecture on Good Friday)

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorials

The tutorial study guides will be available from the course website.

Please aim to attend the tutorial in the fortnight (ie odd or even week) you signed up for.

Tutorial topics:

  1. Australia's 'fair work' system and an introduction to writing advice in employment law? (week 2 or 3)
  2. Identifying employees, employee-like workers, contractor, volunteer etc, and more about writing advice (week 4 or 5)
  3. Wages and renumeration (week 6 or 7)
  4. Disputes about treatment and conduct at work - conciliation conference skills session (week 8 or 9)
  5. Unfair dismissal (week 10 or 11)
  6. Human rights, change and future challenges (week 12 or 13).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
